Integral $\oint_{|z-c|=R} \frac{dz}{z-w} = 2πi$ whenever $|w-c| < R$.

type: ∀ {c w : ℂ} {R : ℝ}, w ∈ Metric.ball c R → (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), (z - w)⁻¹) = 2 * ↑Real.pi * Complex.I
name: circleIntegral.integral_sub_inv_of_mem_ball
docString: Integral $\oint_{|z-c|=R} \frac{dz}{z-w} = 2πi$ whenever $|w-c| < R$.

If a function `f` is differentiable and continuous within the open disc and its closure, then the line integral of `(z - w)⁻¹ * f(z)` around the circle `C(c, R)` equals `2πi * f(w)`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {R : ℝ} {c w : ℂ}
  {f : ℂ → E},
  DiffContOnCl ℂ f (Metric.ball c R) →
    w ∈ Metric.ball c R → (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), (z - w)⁻¹ • f z) = (2 * ↑Real.pi * Complex.I) • f w
name: DiffContOnCl.circleIntegral_sub_inv_smul
docString: If a function `f` is differentiable and continuous within the open disc and its closure, then the line integral of `(z - w)⁻¹ * f(z)` around the circle `C(c, R)` equals `2πi * f(w)`.

This theorem states that for a complex function `f` that is continuous on a closed ball and differentiable in the open ball, where both balls are centered at `c` with radius `R`, and excluding a countable set `s` that does not contain a complex number `w`, the line integral of the function `f` multiplied by the inverse of `(z - w)`, around the circumference of the circle `C(c, R)`, is equal to `2πi` times `f(w)`. This theorem assumes `w` does not belong to the set `s`, while the main theorem associated with this auxiliary lemma relaxes this assumption.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {R : ℝ} {c w : ℂ}
  {f : ℂ → E} {s : Set ℂ},
  s.Countable →
    w ∈ Metric.ball c R \ s →
      ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c R) →
        (∀ x ∈ Metric.ball c R \ s, DifferentiableAt ℂ f x) →
          (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), (z - w)⁻¹ • f z) = (2 * ↑Real.pi * Complex.I) • f w
name: Complex.circleIntegral_sub_inv_smul_of_differentiable_on_off_countable_aux
docString: This theorem states that for a complex function `f` that is continuous on a closed ball and differentiable in the open ball, where both balls are centered at `c` with radius `R`, and excluding a countable set `s` that does not contain a complex number `w`, the line integral of the function `f` multiplied by the inverse of `(z - w)`, around the circumference of the circle `C(c, R)`, is equal to `2πi` times `f(w)`. This theorem assumes `w` does not belong to the set `s`, while the main theorem associated with this auxiliary lemma relaxes this assumption.

If `f : ℂ → E` is continuous on the closed annulus `r ≤ ‖z - c‖ ≤ R`, `0 < r ≤ R`,
and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of its interior,
then the integrals of `f z / (z - c)` (formally, `(z - c)⁻¹ • f z`)
over the circles `‖z - c‖ = r` and `‖z - c‖ = R` are equal to each other.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {c : ℂ} {r R : ℝ},
  0 < r →
    r ≤ R →
      ∀ {f : ℂ → E} {s : Set ℂ},
        Set.Countable s →
          ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c R \ Metric.ball c r) →
            (∀ z ∈ (Metric.ball c R \ Metric.closedBall c r) \ s, DifferentiableAt ℂ f z) →
              (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), (z - c)⁻¹ • f z) = ∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, r), (z - c)⁻¹ • f z
name: Complex.circleIntegral_sub_center_inv_smul_eq_of_differentiable_on_annulus_off_countable
docString:
If `f : ℂ → E` is continuous on the closed annulus `r ≤ ‖z - c‖ ≤ R`, `0 < r ≤ R`,
and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of its interior,
then the integrals of `f z / (z - c)` (formally, `(z - c)⁻¹ • f z`)
over the circles `‖z - c‖ = r` and `‖z - c‖ = R` are equal to each other.

If a complex-valued function `f` is continuous on the closure and differentiable at all but a countable number of points in the open rectangle defined by `z` and `w`, then the integral of `f` around the boundary of the rectangle is zero.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] (f : ℂ → E) (z w : ℂ)
  (s : Set ℂ),
  s.Countable →
    ContinuousOn f (Set.uIcc z.re w.re ×ℂ Set.uIcc z.im w.im) →
      (∀ x ∈ Set.Ioo (min z.re w.re) (max z.re w.re) ×ℂ Set.Ioo (min z.im w.im) (max z.im w.im) \ s,
          DifferentiableAt ℂ f x) →
        (((∫ (x : ℝ) in z.re..w.re, f (↑x + ↑z.im * Complex.I)) - ∫ (x : ℝ) in z.re..w.re, f (↑x + ↑w.im * Complex.I)) +
              Complex.I • ∫ (y : ℝ) in z.im..w.im, f (↑w.re + ↑y * Complex.I)) -
            Complex.I • ∫ (y : ℝ) in z.im..w.im, f (↑z.re + ↑y * Complex.I) =
          0
name: Complex.integral_boundary_rect_eq_zero_of_differentiable_on_off_countable
docString: If a complex-valued function `f` is continuous on the closure and differentiable at all but a countable number of points in the open rectangle defined by `z` and `w`, then the integral of `f` around the boundary of the rectangle is zero.

This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] (f : ℂ → E) (c : ℂ),
  (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z) = 0
name: circleIntegral.integral_radius_zero
docString: This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → ∀ (a b : M), f a = f b
name: MDifferentiable.apply_eq_of_compactSpace
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

If an integrable function has zero integral on all closed sets, then it is zero
almost everwhere.

name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isClosed_eq_zero
docString:
If an integrable function has zero integral on all closed sets, then it is zero
almost everwhere.

A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → IsLocallyConstant f
name: MDifferentiable.isLocallyConstant
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

Integral closures are all isomorphic to each other.

type:
(R : Type u_1) →
  (A : Type u_2) →
    (B : Type u_3) →
      [inst : CommRing R] →
        [inst_1 : CommRing A] →
          [inst_2 : CommRing B] →
            [inst_3 : Algebra R B] →
              [inst_4 : Algebra A B] →
                [inst_5 : IsIntegralClosure A R B] →
                  (A' : Type u_4) →
                    [inst_6 : CommRing A'] →
                      [inst_7 : Algebra A' B] →
                        [inst_8 : IsIntegralClosure A' R B] →
                          [inst_9 : Algebra R A] →
                            [inst_10 : Algebra R A'] →
                              [inst_11 : IsScalarTower R A B] → [inst_12 : IsScalarTower R A' B] → A ≃ₐ[R] A'
name: IsIntegralClosure.equiv
docString: Integral closures are all isomorphic to each other.

Any continuous function on compact Hausdorff spaces is a closed map.

type: ∀ {X Y : CompHaus} (f : X ⟶ Y), IsClosedMap ⇑f
name: CompHaus.isClosedMap
docString: Any continuous function on compact Hausdorff spaces is a closed map.

The integral closure of R in an R-algebra A.

type: (R : Type u_1) → (A : Type u_2) → [inst : CommRing R] → [inst_1 : CommRing A] → [inst_2 : Algebra R A] → Subalgebra R A
name: integralClosure
docString: The integral closure of R in an R-algebra A.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {k : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f → IsCompact k → MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f k
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

If `n ≠ -1` is an integer number, then the integral of `(z - w) ^ n` over the circle equals
zero.

name: circleIntegral.integral_sub_zpow_of_ne
docString:
If `n ≠ -1` is an integer number, then the integral of `(z - w) ^ n` over the circle equals
zero.

If an integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space, then
it is zero almost everwhere.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {β : Type u_3}
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_4 : MeasurableSpace β] [inst_5 : BorelSpace β] [inst_6 : SigmaCompactSpace β]
  [inst_7 : T2Space β] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure β} {f : β → E},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    (∀ (s : Set β), IsCompact s → ∫ (x : β) in s, f x ∂μ = 0) → f =ᶠ[MeasureTheory.Measure.ae μ] 0
name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isCompact_eq_zero
docString:
If an integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space, then
it is zero almost everwhere.

A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is the constant function `f ≡ v`,
for some value `v`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → ∃ v, f = Function.const M v
name: MDifferentiable.exists_eq_const_of_compactSpace
docString:
A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is the constant function `f ≡ v`,
for some value `v`.

Definition for $\oint_{|z-c|=R} f(z)\,dz$.

type: {E : Type u_1} → [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] → [inst : NormedSpace ℂ E] → (ℂ → E) → ℂ → ℝ → E
name: circleIntegral
docString: Definition for $\oint_{|z-c|=R} f(z)\,dz$.

A circle integral which coincides with `deriv f z` whenever one can apply the Cauchy formula for
the derivative. It is useful in the proof that locally uniform limits of holomorphic functions are
holomorphic, because it depends continuously on `f` for the uniform topology.

type: {E : Type u_1} → [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] → [inst : NormedSpace ℂ E] → ℝ → (ℂ → E) → ℂ → E
name: Complex.cderiv
docString:
A circle integral which coincides with `deriv f z` whenever one can apply the Cauchy formula for
the derivative. It is useful in the proof that locally uniform limits of holomorphic functions are
holomorphic, because it depends continuously on `f` for the uniform topology.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on an open neighborhood of any
compact set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f →
    ∀ {k : Set X}, IsCompact k → ∃ u, IsOpen u ∧ k ⊆ u ∧ MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f u
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_nhds_isCompact
docString:
If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on an open neighborhood of any
compact set.

Suppose that a function `f : ℂ → E` is continuous on a closed rectangle with opposite corners at
`z w : ℂ`, is *real* differentiable on the corresponding open rectangle, and
$\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar z}$ is integrable on this rectangle. Then the integral of `f` over
the boundary of the rectangle is equal to the integral of
$2i\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar z}=i\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}$
over the rectangle.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] (f : ℂ → E)
  (f' : ℂ → ℂ →L[ℝ] E) (z w : ℂ),
  ContinuousOn f (Set.uIcc z.re w.re ×ℂ Set.uIcc z.im w.im) →
    (∀ x ∈ Set.Ioo (min z.re w.re) (max z.re w.re) ×ℂ Set.Ioo (min z.im w.im) (max z.im w.im), HasFDerivAt f (f' x) x) →
      MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn (fun z => Complex.I • (f' z) 1 - (f' z) Complex.I)
          (Set.uIcc z.re w.re ×ℂ Set.uIcc z.im w.im) →
        (((∫ (x : ℝ) in z.re..w.re, f (↑x + ↑z.im * Complex.I)) - ∫ (x : ℝ) in z.re..w.re, f (↑x + ↑w.im * Complex.I)) +
              Complex.I • ∫ (y : ℝ) in z.im..w.im, f (↑w.re + ↑y * Complex.I)) -
            Complex.I • ∫ (y : ℝ) in z.im..w.im, f (↑z.re + ↑y * Complex.I) =
          ∫ (x : ℝ) in z.re..w.re,
            ∫ (y : ℝ) in z.im..w.im, Complex.I • (f' (↑x + ↑y * Complex.I)) 1 - (f' (↑x + ↑y * Complex.I)) Complex.I
name: Complex.integral_boundary_rect_of_continuousOn_of_hasFDerivAt_real
docString:
Suppose that a function `f : ℂ → E` is continuous on a closed rectangle with opposite corners at
`z w : ℂ`, is *real* differentiable on the corresponding open rectangle, and
$\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar z}$ is integrable on this rectangle. Then the integral of `f` over
the boundary of the rectangle is equal to the integral of
$2i\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar z}=i\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}$
over the rectangle.

If a locally integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space,
then it is zero almost everwhere.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {β : Type u_3}
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_4 : MeasurableSpace β] [inst_5 : BorelSpace β] [inst_6 : SigmaCompactSpace β]
  [inst_7 : T2Space β] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure β} {f : β → E},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f →
    (∀ (s : Set β), IsCompact s → ∫ (x : β) in s, f x ∂μ = 0) → f =ᶠ[MeasureTheory.Measure.ae μ] 0
name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isCompact_eq_zero'
docString:
If a locally integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space,
then it is zero almost everwhere.

A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace X]
  [inst_4 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasureOnCompacts μ], Continuous f → HasCompactSupport f → MeasureTheory.Integrable f
name: Continuous.integrable_of_hasCompactSupport
docString: A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

The series `∑ z^n/n` converges to `-log (1-z)` on the open unit disk.

type: ∀ {z : ℂ}, ‖z‖ < 1 → HasSum (fun n => z ^ n / ↑n) (-Complex.log (1 - z))
name: Complex.hasSum_taylorSeries_neg_log
docString: The series `∑ z^n/n` converges to `-log (1-z)` on the open unit disk.

If a function has a non-zero strict derivative at all points, then it is an open map.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace 𝕜] {f f' : 𝕜 → 𝕜},
  (∀ (x : 𝕜), HasStrictDerivAt f (f' x) x) → (∀ (x : 𝕜), f' x ≠ 0) → IsOpenMap f
name: open_map_of_strict_deriv
docString: If a function has a non-zero strict derivative at all points, then it is an open map.
